instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01598: What is 820-01598? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power
threads.message: Hi, so on the bench I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that is not powering on. I have 20V @ 40mA on my USB-C ammeter and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 12.62V and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is present at 3.3V. I know since i have 20V at the charger the USB-C controllers are ok, and I have my G3H rails, I don't think my ISL is bad that probably has nothing to do with it I not sure what to look at next.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power
threads.message:
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, a pulse at least?
History fault?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power
threads.message: I have <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, Steady. No history, the owner said it just stopped working. No liquid, no dorps damage. I am trying to see if they tried to update OS.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power
threads.message: Try DFU mode, just in case...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power
threads.message: Is that where I need to use another Macbook?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power
threads.message:
Yes.
Be aware, must have the same macOS version as the one installed in the T2 machine.
